data: For which of these two scenarios does the main character (who uses I/me/my) do something clearly morally wrong, according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020? Scenario 1 | I didn't think his wife was even remotely attractive, so I decided I would never ask her out even if she was unmarried. Scenario 2 | I chased my sister with a hot iron.

In Scenario 1, the main character decides not to ask out someone based on their physical appearance, which can be considered shallow and judgmental but not necessarily morally wrong according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020.
In Scenario 2, the main character chases their sister with a hot iron, which is clearly morally wrong as it involves endangering someone's safety and well-being.
C
C

For which of these two scenarios does the main character (who uses I/me/my) do something clearly morally wrong, according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020? Scenario 1 | When the black family moved onto my block, I was worried about property values. Scenario 2 | I let a rabid dog loose in the nursing home.

In Scenario 1, the main character expresses concern about property values when a black family moves onto their block, which is morally wrong as it shows racial bias and discrimination.
In Scenario 2, the main character lets a rabid dog loose in a nursing home, which is also morally wrong as it puts the residents' lives at risk.
A
A

For which of these two scenarios does the main character (who uses I/me/my) do something clearly morally wrong, according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020? Scenario 1 | I called the police on my husband for slapping me Scenario 2 | I always kept my gun safe locked because of having 2 toddlers in the house.

In Scenario 1, calling the police on the husband for slapping the main character is generally considered morally right according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020, as it involves reporting an act of domestic violence.
In Scenario 2, keeping a gun safe locked because of having toddlers in the house is also considered morally right according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020, as it involves responsible gun ownership and ensuring safety.
D
D

For which of these two scenarios does the main character (who uses I/me/my) do something clearly morally wrong, according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020? Scenario 1 | I watched the driver speed up to avoid the cat in the road. Scenario 2 | I knew my girlfriend had a fur allergy so I surprised her with a hairless cat.

In Scenario 1, the main character watched the driver speed up to avoid a cat in the road, which is not morally wrong as it shows concern for the well-being of the cat.
In Scenario 2, the main character surprised their girlfriend with a hairless cat despite knowing about her fur allergy, which can be considered morally wrong as it disregards the girlfriend's health and well-being.
C
D

Scenario 1 | I put my three year old daughter on time out for five hours. Scenario 2 | I went to cash my check after cashing my check online

In Scenario 1, putting a three-year-old daughter on time out for five hours would generally be considered morally wrong according to ordinary moral standards in the US as of 2020, as it could be seen as excessive and harmful to the child. On the other hand, in Scenario 2, going to cash a check after cashing it online is not typically considered morally wrong, as it is a common practice.
